newsitem.title: GERMANY: FDP urges delay in German Eurofighter procurement.
newsitem.headline: FDP urges delay in German Eurofighter procurement.

text.p: The Free Democrats (FDP), junior partners in Germany's ruling coalition, said on Monday that Bonn's budget woes meant a decision on buying the Eurofighter combat aircraft should be postponed.

Germany's cabinet is due on Tuesday to discuss the purchase of 180 Eurofighters. Defence Minister Volker Ruehe has agreed on a 23 billion mark ($14 billion) price tag with Daimler-Benz Aerospace AG (DASA), the German partner in the four-country project.
"The financing of the procurement is completely unrealistic and cannot be borne by the state budget," FDP deputy Juergen Koppelin, a member of parliament's budget committee, said.
A decision to go ahead and buy the Eurofighter would barely win support when Finance Minister Theo Waigel is likely to slap a freeze on state spending, Koppelin added in a statement.

Government leaders have said they expected parliamentary approval for the Eurofighter procurement to go through during the first quarter of this year. Germany wants to buy 140 standard Eurofighters and 40 modified ground attack aircraft.
Newspapers have reported that Waigel and Ruehe have also reached agreement in principle over splitting the initial extra costs of Germany's Eurofighter force between the defence and federal budgets.

But the money has not been factored into the 1997 budget, which aims to ensure that Germany will qualify for European monetary union in 1999 with a budget deficit of 2.9 percent of gross domestic product. The Maastricht treaty sets a deficit limit of three percent of GDP.
A German decision to buy is eagerly awaited by the three other countries involved in developing the 21st-century combat jet.
Also members of the Eurofighter consortium are British Aerospace, Italy's Alenia Spa and CASA of Spain.
-- Douglas Busvine, Bonn newsroom, 49-228-26097 150 ($ = 1.641 German Marks)
